Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned about different views of how unconscious processes drive behavior

I learned how psychology has developed throughout human history, and specifically how our understanding of conscious and unconscious processes has changed over the past few centuries. The course covers many psychological phenomena relating to the human unconscious and why they occur. I also learned some of the ways that psychological studies are conducted, and how to use the findings of these studies to inform daily life choices. Professor Bargh contextualizes the consequences of unconscious tendencies in a very interesting way, showing students the political and social repercussions, which was fascinating.
This course helps you realize all the ways that your environment, evolution, your relationships, your identity can affect your judgements and decisions without you realizing it.
I learned a lot about how the unconscious mind works, especially in ways that seem obvious in hindsight, but were not obvious at first.
Learned about very cool studies and because aware of a lot of things that impact us.
really insightful class
A lot about unconscious processes, motivations and influences outside of conscious awareness.
Learned about the role of the unconscious.
I learned about unconscious processes that govern much of our behavior.
learned about the conscious mind
Great intro to the unconscious. Very interesting.
Much of the foundational research and studies of modern day social psychology, with a focus on the unconscious processes.
I learned a lot about myself and my unconscious mind. Was interesting material and the professor was a nice guy.
what the unconscious mind is
How the unconscious mind works, what are the characteristics
Learned a lot about the history asnd past philosophy of the Unconscious mind. The course taught some very interesting recent studies done on the unconscious mind.
I developed the knowledge of the uncertainty that lies behind our unconscious.
I learned a lot about the unconscious -- it was interesting to see how we are affected everyday by unconscious stimuli.

-the history of theories about the unconscious mind
-topics such as embodied cognition, unconscious goal pursuit, scaffolding of judgment making on things like hot-cold detection, basic good-bad evaluations, etc.
-there were many topics introduced in class that were actually applicable to my personal understanding of the world and had implications for how I will interact with others going forward

This was an interesting more in depth version of social psych on the unconscious mind, as the title suggests. I learned about many of the unconscious thoughts and processes which was very interesting.

I learned about how the unconscious mind operates with the conscious mind to help us achieve our goals, how to form good habits through implementation intentions, what "system 1 and system 2" really refers to, and more.

I learned all about how unconscious and environmental influences influence our evaluations and behavior in ways you might not expect. The course covers everything from how deep, evolutionary impulses affect us in the present (like the link between our need for physical safety and our political attitudes) to unconscious motivation and whether free will actually exists. Many of the insights and research cited in this class are super relevant to everyday life and are even life hacks!
Nothing
I learned how the conscious and unconscious processes of the brain are integrated and how each system operates.
Thinking about the unconscious critically
I learned how I think and why I think the things I do. It helped me make better decisions I think.
Great lectures and interesting content. I thought the second half of the course was a little repetitive (repeating the same studies over and over again), so maybe this could be improved.

The course is very, very straightforward. Professor Bargh walks the class through every important concept multiple times, and the tests always reflect exactly what was taught. They don't even really require any memorization because the tests always include the name of the study and a basic summary of what the study was about before asking any questions on it, so as long as you went to the lecture or read the book (or got someone's notes) you will be completely set. Professor Bargh's book is also really entertaining and very similar to the lecture, so it's a fun read to reinforce the lecture information before the test, but reading it is probably not essential. There's no discussion section (the TA's do hold office hours though), so it is a very low time commitment, but that does mean you're pretty much on your own in making sure you understand the material (which is not difficult). At times, the lectures can get a bit slow, but I found Professor Bargh to be a very likable, interesting, accomplished instructor and I liked attending the lectures.
This course was well done, I just think some of the central themes could be emphasized a bit more in addition to all the evidence that support these themes.
Very interesting material, but it felt a little disorganized at times.
This is one of my favorite psychology classes, lectures were very engaging and the content was overall very insightful.
material was really interesting and prof was a great lecturer. wasnt always sure what would be covered on the exams though
Lectures are pretty repetitive and dry at times. Could be improved by being more interesting or engaging in some way.
It was a good survey course for the unconscious

strengths: covers good amount of material 
weakness: much of this material is covered in other classrs
Not a very engaging lecture, lots of broad concepts with little connectivity between them.

Course materials are quite poorly organized as there are on average more than 80 pages of PowerPoint each lecture. Much of the content is repetitive, and should be better structured according to theme and focus.
Slides were kinda confusing sometimes and the professor talked through subjects fast.
everything. exams were bad, exam times were bad, grading was bad. it's a mess of a course.
Possible improvements could be made to the point system. Instead of having just two tests encompass the whole grade, maybe add a paper or project.

Interesting content but the lectures were sometimes hard to follow and the grade only rides on two assessments, which can be a lot of pressure. If you consistently go to class, read his book, and make sure to study, the tests are manageable.

The lectures were very interesting, though how topics were connected could have been explained more clearly. Also it was confusing when one piece of evidence was used for many many different units; in all sometimes it was hard to understand distinctions between separate theories/topics (which is fine because there are no discrete categories in our actual mind, but made it harder to explain on tests)

Considering it only has two tests, it was nice to be able to focus on the material but that did make me concerned with how my grade would turn out. But then I took it Credit/d and that turned out perfectly because then I was able to focus on my other classes.

This course was a pretty standard Psychology course, so no major weaknesses except maybe more engaging lectures. I appreciate getting out early though and the detailed review of each experiment during lecture. One thing I did wish was addressed more is how the studies are viewed in the present day, especially given the replication crises and how old some of the studies were.

I think the main strength of the class is simply how interesting and relevant the material is. Lectures were very engaging, and we learned about stuff like how holding coffee can make you perceive someone else as more socially warm. I would have liked for the lectures to incorporate more data and neuroscience. Many of the findings are cool, but Professor Bargh rarely went in depth about the evidence or neurological underpinnings for these processes. While I appreciate that lectures werent too technical, I think we could have gone a little more below the surface. Another facet of the class to be aware of is that the exams are pretty much entirely memorization-based. Its definitely a manageable amount to memorize, but just be aware that you wont be doing much critical thinking or analysis.

A great overview of the conscious and unconscious aspects of the mind. I don't see much room for improvement in the class, although maybe less of a focus on the history of psychology (Skinner/Nicer, etc.) and more on contemporary research. Strong course overall!
The professor put the lectures up on canvas and was a really good lecturer
The lectures were very engaging.
Same slides are used in several classes. The class is very similar to Social Psychology.

Yes! Professor Bargh is a great lecturer and makes lectures interesting to go to.  This class goes over a lot of thought-provoking topics and interesting studies. Although the second half gets a little repetitive, I thought it was still an excellent psych class. If you go to class and study the lecture slides for the midterm and final, you'll get a good grade and don't need to do any additional work.

If they want to correctly understand human behavior, including their own, then yes. This class is more applicable to economics than economics courses at Yale, as it shows how irrational human beings are, and it shows how our economics program exemplifies many problems with education in itself, slow-moving and failing to be pertinent with the times.

Yes, to someone who is interested in psychology and its social effects but does not want to spend lots of time doing outside work, this class is perfect. I'm very glad I took it. Although it is not considered an entry-level course, I had never taken a psych class in my life when I took this class (it was my first semester at Yale in fact), and it required absolutely no background knowledge. As long as you show up to lecture (which absolutely always gets out early), and you take notes, you will be completely set for the midterm and final, which are the only two graded components of this class.

I would recommend this course to another student because throughout the course and still now I still see parallel's between the course content and my own life. Things I have learned in this course have helped explain some of my own judgements and decisions and have helped me see some of the way in which I am biased without realizing it, and helped me think a little more rationally.
Sure.
Absolutely, the content is very interesting and Professor Bargh is a great lecturer.

I don't recommend this class. Professor Bargh may be a giant in his field, but he struggles to lecture with any structure and cannot adequately communicate important general themes. It is also unacceptable to tell students, in a class in which two exams make up a student's course grade, that they should not worry about the intricacies of studies for exams, and then proceed administer exams with 20% or more of the questions being of that EXACT manner.
yes, definitely

Wouldn't really recommend. Teaching was lackluster, basically just repeating the same themes over and over. Feel like I didn't really learn much, but I did find the material itself at least somewhat interesting as factoids, but not much else.

It's ok. Could be a super low workload 5th credit class, but just be aware that the tests are important if the grade is still based on 50% midterm and 50% final. Take it credit D if you're worried about not doing well.
It was an interesting class to those interested in psychology

Yes, take this class if you find the material interesting. The workload is very low and it is well taught, although lectures can be dry and it is best to Credit/D it unless you want to memorize a lot of details.
Yes, really great fifth class with interesting content but minimal work. I thought it was worthwhile.
yes
There is only a midterm and a final. This means very low workload, but hard to turn your grade around. Take with caution.
Course was good but Professor is awful. Pretty boring lecture and he gives out D/D+ like theyre candy. Sounds like a great credit/D but it IS NOT.
I would not recommend this course but I do recommend the other course Social Psychology by Professor Bargh, which is much more organized and inclusive.
Maybe, if they were interested in psych then yes.
Yes
Definitely. Gives you an interesting perspective on cognition.
Yes, it was a great course, where I learned a lot of things about the human mind that I would not realize on my own, but these things happen everyday.
NO. It's a mess of a class that seems like a gut but isn't. Professor really just vomits info at you.
Yes if they are interested in the unconscious and how it affects us
Yes, its interesting in content and has a very low work load. It allows you to really just enjoy what you are learning about.
Yes I would. I think it would be very beneficial for other students to understand a phenomenon that has been shown to dictate and have a great influence on nearly everything we do in life.
It was a very interesting class, so I'm glad I took it. But, it might be better to credit-D it, unless you're fine with the stress of just multiple choice tests, each worth half your grade.
Yes! Its good for people who are curious and also applicable to life
Yes, but take it credit/d. Then you are not concerned about your grade and can focus on enjoying the class without stressing too much over the two tests.

This course was a pretty standard Psych lecture, and the same format as Prof. Bargh's other courses. If you can appreciate his lecture style, then I would definitely recommend this course. He's very knowledgeable about the course material and can make lecture engaging in that sense, but it may also feel somewhat dry or fast-paced. The lectures were usually only an hour long, which I appreciated because I could get lunch before my next class. I personally found this course extremely easy -- if you just come to class and take detailed notes and review them the day before exams, you should do fairly well. The exams were composed of pretty simple multiple choice (everything comes from lecture, you just need to know the main concepts and the studies) and some harder short answer questions. If you can thematically study anything as a potential "list" type question, then it'll probably be a short answer. I found the actual content of this course pretty interesting and somewhat similar to social psych but definitely still worth taking.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course. Even if you arent studying psychology, the findings Professor Bargh discusses in lecture will relate to your life in some way. He takes a very integrative approach, demonstrating the intersection of research with issues like gender biases, race discrimination, philosophy, political leanings, etc. You should note that the course grade is composed of 50% midterm grade and 50% final grade. These exams are totally fair and memorization and lecture-based, and, as long as you do what youre supposed to (like come to lectureswhich are great anyway!), you will do well. I really enjoyed that we were only assessed on the exams, since it meant that I didnt have to write any extra papers or do weekly assignments. Plus there is no section. One more thingif you take the class, definitely buy and read Professor Barghs book. It summarizes the material in a way that's succint and helpful, especially before exams. Again, would really recommend!

No, professor Bargh is not a nice professor. He is condescending to students. His lecture slides are horribly disorganized and impossible to follow. Midterm grade, which is 50% of the grade, comes back after the drop deadline.. so you dont know how youre doing until its too late. Unfortunate class to take.

Take this class! It's a great overview of all the unconscious processes and influences taking place in the brain. Bargh is an expert in the field and an engaging lecturer. He incorporated current events into his teaching, which made the class more relevant. This class really opened my eyes to how my own mind works and how little control I actually have over a lot of my perception and actions. Not much work (straight midterm/final) if you keep up with lectures and are genuinely interested in the material, but not a gut either.
Yes it was very interesting.
Could be an interesting course for someone who hasn't taken any other class in psychology.
